primitive_props.translation: Brendan Rodgers is the Liverpool boss.
primitive_props.evidence: “Liverpool boss Brendan Rodgers believes ...” (opening sentence)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic role/identity statement about a single named person; no logical connective.

primitive_props.translation: Liverpool were knocked out of the FA Cup semi-final by Aston Villa.
primitive_props.evidence: “... Liverpool were knocked out of the FA Cup semi-final by Aston Villa ...” (opening sentence)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic match-outcome statement; not decomposed into smaller propositions without adding extra structure.

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers believes a very poor decision was made by Michael Oliver's assistant referee.
primitive_props.evidence: “... believes a 'very poor decision' by Michael Oliver's assistant referee ...” (opening sentence)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic belief attribution (belief + content) treated as one primitive mental-state report.

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers believes the assistant referee's very poor decision was one of the reasons Liverpool were knocked out.
primitive_props.evidence: “... was one of the reason's Liverpool were knocked out ...” (opening sentence)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic belief about causal contribution as stated; does not include explicit logical connectives.

primitive_props.translation: The semi-final was played on Sunday night at Wembley.
primitive_props.evidence: “... by Aston Villa on Sunday night. With the score ... at Wembley ...” (first paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic spatiotemporal setting claim.

primitive_props.translation: With five minutes left, Aston Villa were leading 2-1.
primitive_props.evidence: “With the score at 2-1 and just five minutes left ...” and “With Aston Villa leading 2-1 ...” (early paragraphs)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic game-state claim at a specific time.

primitive_props.translation: Mario Balotelli had the ball in the net.
primitive_props.evidence: “... Mario Balotelli had the ball in the net ...” (early paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic event statement; no connectives.

primitive_props.translation: The linesman (assistant referee) flagged for offside.
primitive_props.evidence: “... only to see the linesman ... flag for offside.” (early paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic officiating action; does not assert whether offside was true.

primitive_props.translation: The linesman unfairly flagged for offside.
primitive_props.evidence: “... the linesman unfairly flag for offside.” (early paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic evaluative claim about the flag’s fairness (as asserted by the text).

primitive_props.translation: Replays clearly showed that Leandro Bacuna was playing Balotelli onside.
primitive_props.evidence: “Replays clearly showed that ... Bacuna was playing Balotelli onside ...” (early paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic claim about what the replays showed.

primitive_props.translation: Mario Balotelli was onside.
primitive_props.evidence: “... showing him to be onside ...” and “Balotelli ... is clearly onside ...” (early paragraphs)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic positional/factual claim.

primitive_props.translation: Balotelli slid the ball past Shay Given.
primitive_props.evidence: “... before the Italian slid the ball past Shay Given.” (early paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic action event involving two participants.

primitive_props.translation: Balotelli's effort would not count (his goal did not count).
primitive_props.evidence: “... before realising his effort would n't count.” (caption/nearby sentence)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic match-adjudication outcome regarding the attempt.

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers told BT Sport after Liverpool's defeat.
primitive_props.evidence: “Speaking after his side's defeat, Rodgers told BT Sport ...” (mid text)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic speech-act report (who spoke to whom and when).

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers said the official was looking right along the line.
primitive_props.evidence: “... because he's looking right along the line.” (Rodgers quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers said the official should be able to see the full back was playing Balotelli at least a yard onside.
primitive_props.evidence: “He should be able to see the full back is playing him at least a yard onside.” (Rodgers quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic normative/ability statement as reported speech (no connectives).

primitive_props.translation: Balotelli criticized the decision.
primitive_props.evidence: “Balotelli also criticised the decision ...” (mid text)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic stance/attitude report.

primitive_props.translation: Balotelli posted a screen-grab of the incident to Instagram with the message 'No words. This picture say it all.'
primitive_props.evidence: “... posting a screen-grab ... to his Instagram page, with the message 'No words ...'” (mid text)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic social-media action with associated content.

primitive_props.translation: Philippe Coutinho gave Liverpool a 1-0 lead (Coutinho scored to make it 1-0).
primitive_props.evidence: “Philippe Coutinho gives Liverpool a 1-0 lead ...” (later paragraph/caption)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic scoring/outcome statement.

primitive_props.translation: The game was all-square six minutes later after Christian Benteke swept home from 12 yards.
primitive_props.evidence: “The semi-final showpiece was all-square just six minutes later after Christian Benteke swept home from 12-yards out ...” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic match-state change event with time reference.

primitive_props.translation: Benteke's goal followed a neat cut-back from Fabian Delph.
primitive_props.evidence: “... following a neat cut-back from Fabian Delph.” (same paragraph as Benteke goal)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic causal/sequence description of the goal’s assist.

primitive_props.translation: Rodgers admitted he was left frustrated by the assistant referee's decision.
primitive_props.evidence: “Liverpool boss Brendan Rodgers admitted he was left frustrated by the assistant referee's decision.” (mid text)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported admission of an emotional state with its target.

primitive_props.translation: Fabian Delph scored a 53rd-minute strike.
primitive_props.evidence: “... earned his side a place ... with a 53rd-minute strike ...” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic scoring event with time reference.

primitive_props.translation: Aston Villa earned a place in the FA Cup final.
primitive_props.evidence: “The Villains captain earned his side a place in the FA Cup final ...” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic competition-progression outcome statement.

primitive_props.translation: Liverpool threw on Rickie Lambert in the final stages.
primitive_props.evidence: “... despite throwing on Rickie Lambert in the final stages.” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic substitution/action statement.

primitive_props.translation: Liverpool were unable to respond.
primitive_props.evidence: “... as Liverpool were unable to respond ...” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic performance/outcome statement (no internal connectives).

primitive_props.translation: Delph told BT Sport after the game.
primitive_props.evidence: “Speaking after the game, Delph told BT Sport ...” (later paragraph)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic speech-act report.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said it was a great performance.
primitive_props.evidence: “It was a great performance.” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said it has been a tricky season for Aston Villa.
primitive_props.evidence: “It's been a tricky season for us ...” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said Aston Villa believed they could do it.
primitive_props.evidence: “... but we believed we could do it.” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported belief attribution.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said the gaffer is brilliant.
primitive_props.evidence: “The gaffer is brilliant ...” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said the gaffer does not panic.
primitive_props.evidence: “... he doesn't panic ...” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said they are so happy for the fans.
primitive_props.evidence: “... we are so happy for the fans.” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said he can't wait for the final.
primitive_props.evidence: “I can't wait for the final.” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph said walking out as captain for the final will be the highlight of his career.
primitive_props.evidence: “To walk out as captain for the final will be the highlight of my career.” (Delph quote)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic reported-speech content.

primitive_props.translation: Delph was mobbed by his Villa team-mates after putting Tim Sherwood's side into a deserved 2-1 lead.
primitive_props.evidence: “Fabian Delph is mobbed by his Villa team-mates after putting Tim Sherwood's side into a deserved 2-1 lead.” (final line/caption)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic event description (being mobbed) with a stated context.

primitive_props.translation: Balotelli was unhappy about the offside decision.
primitive_props.evidence: Implied by: “Balotelli also criticised the decision ... 'No words.'” (mid text)
primitive_props.explanation: Atomic affective state inferred from criticism/posting; can be true/false without connectives.

hard_constraints.translation: If Rodgers believes the decision was a reason for being knocked out, then he believes it was a very poor decision and (in the described world) Liverpool were knocked out.
hard_constraints.evidence: Opening sentence ties the belief to both 'very poor decision' and 'knocked out'.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic unpacking of the belief claim: the stated causal-belief presupposes the poor-decision belief and references the knockout.

hard_constraints.translation: If replays clearly showed Bacuna played Balotelli onside, then Balotelli was onside.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Replays clearly showed ... playing ... onside ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense semantic link: authoritative replay evidence entails the described onside status.

hard_constraints.translation: If Balotelli was onside, then the offside flag was unfair/incorrect.
hard_constraints.evidence: Narrative contrasts onside replay with offside flag.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic rule of football officiating: onside implies an offside call is wrong.

hard_constraints.translation: If the flag was unfair, then a flag occurred.
hard_constraints.evidence: “... unfairly flag ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Unfair-flag description presupposes the flag event.

hard_constraints.translation: The goal did not count exactly because the linesman flagged for offside (as described).
hard_constraints.evidence: “... had the ball in the net only to see the linesman ... flag for offside.” + “... effort wouldn't count.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Text indicates the disallowance is tied to the offside flag; treated as an iff to capture the narrative linkage.

hard_constraints.translation: If Balotelli had the ball in the net (in that described incident), then his effort did not count.
hard_constraints.evidence: “... had the ball in the net only to see ... flag ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The event is presented as a disallowed goal incident.

hard_constraints.translation: If Balotelli slid the ball past Shay Given (as described in that incident), then he had the ball in the net.
hard_constraints.evidence: “... slid the ball past Shay Given.” immediately within the disallowed-goal description
hard_constraints.reasoning: In context, sliding the ball past the keeper is the described scoring action; semantic entailment within the narrative.

hard_constraints.translation: If Balotelli posted the screen-grab with that message, then he criticized the decision.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Balotelli also criticised ... posting ... with the message ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Posting the screen-grab with 'No words' is presented as the vehicle of the criticism.

hard_constraints.translation: If the game was all-square six minutes later, then Liverpool must have had the earlier 1-0 lead.
hard_constraints.evidence: Lead described, then: “all-square just six minutes later ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic constraint: 'all-square six minutes later' refers back to the immediately preceding 1-0 lead.

hard_constraints.translation: If Benteke's goal followed Delph's cut-back, then Benteke scored the equalizer described.
hard_constraints.evidence: Benteke goal sentence includes the cut-back clause.
hard_constraints.reasoning: The 'followed by' clause is part of the same goal event description.

hard_constraints.translation: If Rodgers was frustrated by the assistant referee's decision, then the assistant referee made an offside-flag decision.
hard_constraints.evidence: Rodgers frustration is explicitly tied to “the assistant referee's decision” in the offside incident context.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic presupposition: being frustrated by that decision implies that decision occurred (the offside flag).

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph scored the 53rd-minute strike (as described), then Aston Villa earned a place in the FA Cup final.
hard_constraints.evidence: “... earned ... a place ... with a 53rd-minute strike ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The text explicitly links the strike to earning the final place.

hard_constraints.translation: Liverpool being knocked out by Aston Villa in this semi-final is equivalent to Aston Villa earning a place in the FA Cup final.
hard_constraints.evidence: Both claims describe the same semi-final outcome and its consequence.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense tournament semantics: in a semi-final, the winner reaches the final and the loser is knocked out.

hard_constraints.translation: If Liverpool threw on Rickie Lambert in the final stages (in this described context), then Liverpool were unable to respond.
hard_constraints.evidence: “... unable to respond despite throwing on Rickie Lambert ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The 'despite' construction asserts both substitution and inability-to-respond.

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said it was a great performance, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Delph quote is introduced by “Delph told BT Sport ...”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Quoted statements are attributed to the BT Sport interview context.

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said the season has been tricky, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said they believed they could do it, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said the gaffer is brilliant, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said the gaffer doesn't panic, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said they are happy for the fans, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said he can't wait for the final, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph said captaining the final would be his career highlight, then Delph told BT Sport after the game.
hard_constraints.evidence: Same Delph quote block

hard_constraints.translation: If Delph put Sherwood's side into a 2-1 lead (as stated), then with five minutes left Aston Villa were leading 2-1 (consistent game state).
hard_constraints.evidence: Caption about “2-1 lead” + earlier game state description
hard_constraints.reasoning: Semantic consistency constraint: the described 2-1 lead aligns with the later-referenced 2-1 lead near the end.

soft_constraints.translation: If Balotelli criticized the decision, then Balotelli was unhappy about it.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Common-sense inference from criticism/complaint language to negative affect; not strictly logically necessary.

soft_constraints.translation: If Rodgers was frustrated by the decision, then Rodgers believes it was a very poor decision.
soft_constraints.evidence: Rodgers frustration is discussed alongside his “very poor decision” comments.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Frustration often accompanies judging the decision as poor, but could occur for other reasons; thus defeasible.
